title: 107_hr3332
content: The "Attorney Fee Payment System Improvement Act of 2001" increases the maximum allowable attorney fee and caps attorney assessments under the Social Security Act. The maximum allowable attorney fee is raised to $5,200 and the cap on attorney assessments is set at $100. Additionally, the Act extends the attorney fee payment system to Title XVI claims. Section 1631(d)(2) of the Social Security Act is amended to update certain provisions related to attorney fees. The Social Security Act is amended to update provisions related to attorney fees by substituting phrases and making changes in various subsections. The Social Security Act is amended to update provisions related to attorney fees by substituting phrases and making changes in various subsections. The amendment includes provisions for payment of past-due benefits to claimants represented by attorneys, with specific conditions outlined for the calculation and reduction of such payments. The Social Security Act is amended to update provisions related to attorney fees, including payment of past-due benefits to claimants represented by attorneys. Attorneys may receive a fee equal to 25 percent of past-due benefits, with an additional assessment imposed by the Commissioner not exceeding $100. The Commissioner determines a percentage rate for full recovery of costs from attorneys' fees, not exceeding 6.3 percent. The assessment can be collected from a claimant's past-due benefits. Attorneys cannot seek reimbursement from claimants for the assessment. Collected assessments are deposited in a separate Treasury fund. The assessments authorized under this subparagraph are collected and available for obligation only as provided in advance in appropriations Acts. Appropriated amounts remain available until expended for administrative expenses related to this title and related laws. The amendments made by this Act will apply to fees for representation of claimants required to be certified under the Social Security Act after 180 days from the enactment of this Act.
